column1: 0104|four minutes past one|The electric timepiece on the roofs marked four minutes past one as they rattled past. What people were still awake were most of them inside the shining windows of the restaurants
column2: and the big porters were leaning sleepily against the doorposts of their hostelries. In the cab Ralston wondered what the President would say if he could see him then
column3: chasing all over the town after a young woman and her male escort.

column1: 0104|1:04|She had called twice during the twenty-four hours following the old bastard’s stroke
column2:
when it became obvious he was going to snuff it. The phone had not been answered either time.
She called again after her father died — this time at 1:04 on the morning of August 2nd. Some drunk had answered the telephone.
